The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?

What is your overall assessment of this course?

Comments_List: IO, LCA being used to evaluate carbon footprint. I also learned a lot of MATLAB

Learning how to use Input-output model
Using Matlab to calculate carbon footprints
I'm not sure I ended up with any new skill, aside from learning some codes on matlab, which I'm never going to use again in my life.
Working understanding of environmentally-extended I/O; basic proficiency in MatLab
Concepts about carbon footprints, the use of Matlab and different skills such as presentation and analysis.
Matlab technical ability. Input-output table analysis. Understanding of Scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions in a supply chain
Matlab, analysis of I/O tables, a rigorous approach to carbon accounting
Class provided an introduction into how to use Matlab software to conduct carbon footprint accounting and analysis, as well as a background of the theory behind carbon footprinting.
Understanding of input-output analysis for carbon footprinting, understanding of literature on carbon footprinting, Matlab.

Understanding of carbon footprint modelling and analysis techniques; practice with carbon footprint modelling and analysis. I also got a better understanding of how carbon footprinting can be used in different situations, and the type of questions that can be answered using this tool.
Matlab, input-output analysis, quite a bit about the impacts of economic systems on the environment and potential mitigations.
Beyond my expectation
Very well
This course helps me to form deeper understanding on different IO models and the practice part with Matlab is  really good!

Not at all. I'm terribly disappointed about this class. We only focused on macroeconomic models and extremely high level carbon footprint analysis that are not translatable to any other country aside from the OECD countries, China and India. We had only two lectures on organizations and buildings' carbon footprint, but we didn't learn how to calculate their carbon footprint nor had any activity on them, which was the main reason I joined the class.
While the class wasn't always what I wished it was along the way, I finished it with skills I hoped to develop when I signed up for the class.
I learned more than I expected before the class.
Became more proficient in technical ability in Matlab than seemed possible going in
I think it was much more technical and focused on one way of doing things (manipulating tables in Matlab) than I had expected. I was hoping to gain more different kinds of skills.

Medium. I expected a much stronger focus on practical skills in terms of implementing carbon footprinting analysis, but left feeling like I was still fumbling around with the basics of the software, despite feeling like I more or less understood the theory.
Lecture was very interesting and I have a good grasp of how academics are applying IO for carbon footprinting I'm less competent with Matlab than I expected.

Overall, the experience from class was relatively well aligned with expectations. One aspect that was not aligned with my expectations was that I expected to learn more coding skills from the class and also more advanced forms of analysis (skills like STIRPAT) from the class.
The computer classes are quite helpful.

The course was excellent in teaching a concept or premise, and cementing the knowledge with a relevant assignment immediately.
Might have helped if I had discussed problem sets from the start with others, though thats my bad.

Strength: theory combining practice
Weakness: /

The main weakness of the class was the poor quality in the delivery of the lectures. Professor Hertwich was not prepared for the classes and rushed through the slides without giving any background information and simply showing a lot of formulas that were incomprehensible and unrealistic to even attempt to explain in 10 seconds per slide, without even including the reference of what each formula/letter meant in the same slide.
In addition, the lectures on MatLab had the same drawbacks, as the professor would be writing the codes (arriving to the correct formula after several attempts, showing that he didn't prepare for the class) at the same time that he would be explaining super fast what he was trying to do, with many codes being completely new to the class and he not explaining what they meant nor what they were intending to do. Imagine trying to type a code on your computer, understand what the new code means, understand what the professor is intending to do, and rushing to the next code with lacking explanation, all at same time.

The structure of the lectures felt a little arbitrary at times; it was hard to suss out conceptual relationships both within and between lectures. A higher level view may have helped to organize the information and communicate the significance of particular subjects that we encountered along the way.
Great way to learn how to use Matlab for analysis. However, there are some big jumps in difficulties between some homework.

I ended up learning a lot, but many of the tutorials were not very well organized and frankly misleading, as the prof would sometimes himself get confused in the middle of showing something. I think it wouldn't take too much work to streamline the lectures--the confusing parts that have to be edited out mid-class are what makes learning the most difficult.

The course should be more focused on practical applications, with more time for students to work with the professor and teaching assistant to learn the skills taught in the class. My questions were rarely answered in office answers and I fumbled around on the homeworks without feeling like I learned anything.
Strengths: lectures, project. Weaknesses: lab instruction (learning Matlab), not enough support for HW.

The class was well-organized and quite well-structured for learning. 1 lecture and 1 lab session a week was good for learning concepts and theories and subsequently applying those concepts and theories.
Edgar just left... Sorry for you guys
Keep up with the assignments and classes since day 1 and it should be a fun learning experience. Also make full use of office hours!
Matlab part is not very difficult and if you want to learn how to use IO model, you should take this course.

I was terribly disappointed with this class and wouldn't recommend it to anyone. The amount of work it required per week was extremely high for the very lacking lectures, and you will only ever use again the teachings of this class if you work on academia or research about whole-country economies carbon footprint calculations. This class won't help you to calculate carbon footprints of anything smaller than that--smaller products, buildings, organizations.

Learn some MatLab and get a handle on the basic vocabulary of input/output analysis beforehand--this class won't hold your hand through introductory material; the language of the assignments is largely inscrutable so don't be shy about asking for clarification on every point
Do not miss any lecture or lab sections and go to office hour for homework helps.
Take it for sure for a set of specific skills, but know in advance that you will be doing IO analysis in Matlab basically the whole time.
Start homeworks early and work with friends, because the teaching assistant might not actually be willing to help you.
Difficult class. Take for understanding of carbon footprint analaysis, not for picking up software skills.

It is a useful course that you should definitely take if you are interested in the topic! I believe it would be useful for the working world as well, especially if you are working in consulting related/energy related roles.
